metadata.title: Salicylaldehyde-functional block copolymer nano-objects: one-pot synthesis via polymerization-induced self-assembly and their simultaneous cross-linking and fluorescent modification

sections.text:
Salicylaldehyde-functional diblock copolymer nano-objects were synthesized by polymerization induced self-assembly (PISA) via RAFT dispersion polymerization of a newly designed core-forming monomer, 3-formyl-4-hydroxybenzyl methacrylate (FHMA), using poly(2-hydroxypropyl methacrylate) (PHPMA) macromolecular chain transfer agent as a steric stabilizer in methanol at 65 oC. A range of PHPMA-b-PFHMA block copolymer morphologies including sphere, worm and vesicle could be accessed by adjusting the degree of polymerization of core forming block PFHMA. Since the salicylaldehyde groups of core-forming PFHMA blocks
P ol
ym er
C he
m is
Pu bl
could react with hydrazine in a 2:1 stoichiometry to form salicylaldazines with aggregation-induced emission, one-step post-modification of the PISA nano-objects using hydrazine enabled their inherent nanostructures to be stabilized via covalent cross-linking and simultaneously conferred luminescent features on the resulting stabilized nanoparticles. Solid nano-objects, obtained easily via precipitation into diethyl ether, could be re-dispersed well in methanol and THF. The nano-objects could also be re-dispersed in water to form colloidal dispersions at a low concentration (≤ 1% w/w). Thanks to the stability imparted by the cross-linking, the morphologies of the preformed PISA nano-objects remained intact even after re-dispersing these cross-linked nano-objects in THF (a good solvent for both blocks). The stabilized nano-objects displayed strong orange fluorescence in water, organic solvents or solid states. This work opens the possibility for simultaneous functionlization and stabilization of PISA-generated block copolymer nano-objects.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Amphiphilic diblock copolymers can undergo self-assembly in a selective solvent to form nano-objects with various morphologies (most often spheres).1-6 These block copolymer nano-objects have received much attention in the past decades owing their numerous potential applications, for instance in nanomedicine, cosmetics, catalysis and sensing.5-10. However, preparation of block copolymer nano-objects requires time consuming multiple-steps, including generally synthesis, characterization, and purification of amphiphilic copolymers followed by their self-assembly in selective
P ol

solvents and solvent displacement. Meanwhile, the self-assemblies can only be accomplished in dilute solution (typically < 1 wt %), limiting large-scale production and thus many potential commercial applications.1-13 Recently, the so-called polymerization induced self-assembly (PISA) has been demonstrated to be a robust and efficient route for the direct in situ synthesis of block copolymer nano-objects of various morphologies at relatively high copolymer concentrations (up to 50 % solids).14-17 PISA strategy is usually based on controlled/living radical polymerizations, particularly reversible addition-fragmentation chain transfer (RAFT) polymerization due to the mild reaction condition and functional group tolerance.18,19 In RAFT-mediated PISA systems, a soluble macromolecular chain transfer agent (macro-CTA) is chain-extended with a second monomer in a suitable solvent that is selected to be a nonsolvent for the growing second block. The first soluble block confers steric stabilization, while the growing insoluble block drives in situ self-assembly to form block copolymer nano-objects. By varying the relative volume fractions of each block, a wide range of morphologies such as sphere, worm and vesicle can be obtained. Up to now RAFT-mediated PISA has been achieved via emulsion polymerization20 or dispersion polymerization in either aqueous,21 alcoholic22, 23 or non-polar media.16
Even though versatility and facility of RAFT-mediated PISA in the direct
preparation of well-defined block copolymer self-assemblies, there is still a relatively limited number of monomers that have been employed for the core-forming blocks and therefore the core polymer of PISA-generated nano-assemblies generally lacks

functionality15. Styrene,24-27 some common methacrylates (often benzyl methacrylate28-30 and 2-hydroxypropyl methacrylate31-34) and N-isopropylacrylamide35-37 are mostly employed as core monomers for PISA; functional monomers, especially monomers containing highly reactive groups, are seldom found in PISA formulations presumably due to the difficulties of controlling in situ self-assembly of functional core-forming polymers.38-42 One of the few examples is the use of diacetone acrylamide as core monomer to synthesize block copolymer nano-objects with a ketone-functionalized core via aqueous RAFT-mediated PISA.43 These ketone-containing nano-objects could be further functionalized via oxime or hydrazone chemistry, however such modification tended to result in a loss of structural integrity or colloidal stability. Therefore developing new functional core monomers is currently essential to introduce functionalities into PISA-generated nano-objects and thus extend their potential applications.
Like their traditional counterparts, PISA-generated block copolymer assemblies
are also dynamic structures and will be disassembled into unimers at very dilute concentration or in a better solvent for core-forming chains. Environment fluctuations in, for example, pH, ionic strength, or temperature can also influence assembly stability. Therefore stabilization of self-assembled structures is necessary or mandatory in some cases when high resistance to external stimulus is required. The most efficient way to stabilize block copolymer assemblies produced by PISA is chemical cross-linking, and both in situ and post-polymerization cross-linking approaches have been exploited.43 In situ cross-linking uses a bifunctional monomer
P ol

such as N,N’-methylenebisacrylamide as the cross-linker during PISA.35,40 However, the chain rearrangement during polymerization, which drives the morphological transition to produce anisotropic structures, is hindered by in situ cross-linking. In order to obtain cross-linked nano-objects with higher order morphologies, the bifunctional monomer must be added at high monomer conversions when morphology transition has completed.45,46 Obviously, the delayed introduction of the bifunctional monomer should lead to a heterogeneous distribution of cross-linking units within the formed nano-objects, which may reduce their morphological stability.43 Homogeneously cross-linked structures can be reached by post-polymerization strategy using organic chemical reactions for cross-linking of the preformed nano-objects. However, mild and efficient chemistry for post-polymerization cross-linking is highly desirable to avoid a loss of structural integrity or colloidal stability after post-polymerization derivatization.
In the present work, we demonstrate for the first time (1) a facile PISA synthesis
of salicylaldehyde-functionalized block copolymer nano-objects with various morphologies using a newly designed reactive core-forming monomer, 3-formyl-4-hydroxybenzyl methacrylate (FHMA), and (2) simultaneous incorporation of luminescent feature and cross-linking structure into the resulting nano-objects via a one-step post-polymerization derivatization. As shown in Scheme 1, RAFT dispersion polymerization of FHMA was conducted in methanol employing poly(2-hydroxypropyl methacrylate) (PHPMA) chain transfer agent as the stabilizing block to in situ produce PHPMA-b-PFHMA block copolymer

nano-objects containing reactive salicylaldehyde groups in their cores. A full range of pure copolymer morphologies including sphere, worm and vesicle could be obtained by adjusting, for example, the length of core-forming PFHMA block. It has been demonstrated that salicylaldehyde can react rapidly with hydrazine in a 2:1 stoichiometry at room temperature to form salicylaldazine that shows aggregation-induced emission (AIE) characteristics.47 Therefore the salicylaldehyde groups positioned in the core of the PHPMA-b-PFHMA nano-objects were subsequently reacted with hydrazine, endowing the nano-objects with not only luminescent features but also cross-linking structure in consequence of the formation of salicylaldazine moieties within the nano-object cores (see Scheme 1). Fluorescent polymeric nanomaterials may find promising applications in labeling, sensing and imaging for biological and environmental systems.48-52 Thanks to the mild and efficient nature of salicylaldehyde-hydrazine reaction, the morphologies of the preformed self-assemblies remained intact after this post-modification. This is the first attempt of simultaneous functionlization and stabilization for PISA-generated block copolymer assemblies.

sections.heading: Materials
sections.text:
2-Hydroxypropyl methacrylate (HPMA; J&K, 97%) was passed through a
column of basic alumina to remove inhibitor and then stored at -20 °C prior to use. 2, 2′-Azobis(isobutyronitrile) (AIBN; Sinopharm Chemical Reagent, 99%) was purified by recrystallization from ethanol. 4-Cyano-4-(propylthiocarbonothioylthio)pentanoic acid (CPPA)53 and 5-(chloromethyl)-2-hydroxybenzaldehyde54 were synthesized according to literature procedures. Other reagents were all analytical grade and used as received.

sections.heading: Synthesis of 3-formyl-4-hydroxybenzyl methacrylate (FHMA)
sections.text:
A mixture of methacrylic acid (25.8 g, 0.3 mol), sodium hydroxide (12.0 g, 0.3

mol) and water (300 mL) was stirred at room temperature for 30 min. Then 5-(chloromethyl)-2-hydroxybenzaldehyde (51.2 g, 0.3 mol), potassium iodide (10.0 g, 0.02 mol) and toluene (60 mL) were added successively to the above aqueous solution. The reaction mixture was heated to 50 °C and stirred overnight. The mixture was extracted with ethyl acetate (50 mL×3), and the organic extract was dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. After filtration, the volatiles were removed by a rotary evaporator. The residue was purified by column chromatography on silica gel with petroleum ether/ethyl acetate (9:1) to give FHMA as a white solid (48.6 g, 74.0 %). 1H NMR (CDCl3), δ (TMS, ppm): 1.97 (s, 3H, CH3C=CH2), 5.16 (s, 2H, COOCH2), 5.60 (s, 1H, cis-CH2=), 6.14 (s, 1H, trans-CH2=), 7.00 (d, J = 8.46 Hz, 1H, 5-aromtic proton), 7.56 (d, J = 8.24 Hz, 1H, 4-aromtic proton), 7.60 (s, 1H, 2-aromtic proton), 9.89 (s, 1H, -CHO), 11.04 (s, 1H, -OH). Anal. Calcd for C12H12O4: C 65.45; H 5.49. Found: C 65.21; H 5.71. FAB MS: m/z calcd for C32H50O4S3 220.07; found 220 (M+).
Synthesis of poly(2-hydroxypropyl methacrylate) macro-chain transfer agent
(PHPMA macro-CTA)
In a typical protocol, an ampule equipped with a magnetic stir bar was charged
with HPMA (6.0 g, 41.6 mmol), CPPA (115.2 mg, 416 µmol; target DP = 100), AIBN (13.5 mg, 8.4 µmol) and methanol (6 mL), then degassed by three freeze-pump-thaw cycles, sealed under N2, and heated at 65 °C. After 3.5 h (60% HPMA conversion, determined via 1H NMR spectroscopy), the polymerization was quenched by cooling to 0 °C. The reaction mixture was diluted with methanol and then poured into a large

amount of diethyl ether. The precipitate was washed with ether and dried under vacuum to give 2.84 g of PHPMA macro-CTA. 1H NMR analysis indicated a mean degree of polymerization of 64 for PHPMA macro-CTA (PHPMA64 macro-CTA).
RAFT dispersion polymerization of FHMA with PHPMA macro-CTA in
methanol
A typical RAFT dispersion polymerization conducted at 15 wt % solids targeting
PHPMA64-PFHMA200 was as follows: An ampule equipped with a magnetic stir bar was charged with PHPMA64 macro-CTA (100.0 mg, 10.5 µmol), FHMA (462.0 mg, 2.1 mmol), AIBN (0.6 mg, 3.5 µmol) and methanol (3.2 g), then degassed by three freeze-pump-thaw cycles, sealed under N2, and heated at 65 °C for 24 h. The reaction was quenched by cooling in an ice bath. An aliquot was withdrawn and analyzed by GPC, 1H NMR, SEM and TEM.
Formation of cross-linked fluorescent nano-objects
For a typical procedure, the PHPMA52-PFHMA60 dispersion (15 wt% solids),
obtained by the RAFT dispersion polymerization as described above, was directly diluted 5-fold with methanol. To this diluted dispersion was added dropwise a solution of hydrazine hydrate (0.5 equiv. to FHMA units) in methanol (1 mL), and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 2 h. After purification via precipitation into excess diethyl ether, the cross-linking stabilized fluorescent nano-objects were obtained as a yellow powder. The solid nano-objects were re-dispersed in methanol or

sections.heading: Characterization
sections.text:
1H NMR spectra was recorded on an AVANCE III 400MHz spectrometer. The number-average molecular weight (Mn), and molecular weight distribution (Mw/Mn) were measured by gel permeation chromatography (GPC) against polystyrene standard in THF at a flow rate of 1.0 mL min-1 at 35 oC on three Waters Styragel columns (measurable molecular weight range: 100–5000, 500–30000, and 5000–600000) connected to a Waters 1515 pump and a Waters 2414 refractive index detector. Fluorescence spectra and absolute quantum yields were recorded on an Edinburgh FLS 980 photoluminescence spectrometer. UV-Vis adsorption spectra were recorded on a PGENERAL TU-1901 UV-vis spectrophotometer at 25 oC. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded on a Nicolet NEXUSe670 FTIR spectrometer.
Dynamic light scattering (DLS) measurements were conducted at 25 oC on a
Brookhaven BI-200SM apparatus with a BI-9000AT digital correlator and a He-Ne laser at 532 nm. The data were analyzed by CONTIN algorithm.
Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) observations were made on a Hitachi
S-4800 Field-Emission-Gun SEM. The samples for SEM observations were prepared by casting a drop of diluted dispersion solution (0.15 % w/w) on a polished silicon wafer, followed by drying under ambient conditions. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) studies were conducted with a Tecnai G2 Spirit TEM at an

sections.heading: Synthesis of monomer 3-formyl-4-hydroxybenzyl methacrylate (FHMA)
sections.text:
A novel salicylaldehyde functionalized methacrylate monomer FHMA was designed and synthesized readily by the reaction of methacrylic acid with 5-(chloromethyl)-2-hydroxybenzaldehyde (Scheme 1). The structure of FHMA was confirmed on the base of the elemental analysis, MS, and 1H NMR spectroscopy. The 1H NMR spectrum (Fig. 1) exhibits the characteristic signals corresponding to methacrylic vinyl (a,b), aldehyde (i) and hydroxyl (h) moieties. The other signals were also assigned as shown in Fig. 1.

Fig. 1. 1H NMR spectra of FHMA in CDCl3.
Synthesis of PHPMA-PFHMA block copolymer nano-objects with various
morphologies In this study, poly(2-hydroxypropyl methacrylate) (PHPMA)55 was utilized as both RAFT macro-CTA and stabilizer for the RAFT dispersion polymerization of FHMA in methanol to in situ produce nano-objects of block copolymer PHPMA-b-PFHMA. The initial solution RAFT polymerization of HPMA was conducted in methanol at 65 °C for 3.5 h (~60% HPMA conversion) utilizing AIBN initiator and CPPA as the RAFT agent to generate a near-monodisperse (Mw/Mn=1.18) PHPMA macro-CTA with a number-average degree of polymerization (DP) of 64 (PHPMA64). After purification, this PHPMA64 macro-CTA was then used for the RAFT dispersion polymerization of FHMA in methanol at 15 wt% solids, while the target DP of the PFHMA chains was systematically increased from 200 to 300. Methanol was chosen as the polymerization medium because it was a good solvent of FHMA monomer and PHPMA macro-CTA but a non-solvent of the PFHMA block, which is essential for the in situ synthesis of the block copolymer nano-objects under PISA condition. Since the PFHMA chains are insoluble in methanol, a range of block copolymer morphologies should in principle be generated via in situ self-assembly by varying the DP of the core-forming PFHMA chains. Indeed, the initially homogeneous mixture became increasingly turbid as the FHMA polymerization proceeded, indicating nucleation and in situ self-assembly of the growing diblock copolymer. More than

99 % FHMA conversion was achieved within 24 h at 65 oC in all polymerizations as judged by 1H NMR analysis, which is important for the synthesis of high-quality diblock copolymers.
After purification by precipitation into excess diethyl ether, the resulting PHPMA64-PFHMAx (x denotes the DP for FHMA block) block copolymers were characterized by GPC and 1H NMR. As shown in Fig. 2, PHPMA64-PFHMAx block copolymers displayed invariably narrow and unimodal GPC traces (Mw/Mn < 1.20) shifting to higher molecular weight region relative to the PHPMA64 macro-CTA, with increasing Mn being observed when targeting higher DP of PFHMA. These indicated the formation of well-defined PHPMA64-PFHMAx block copolymers.

PHPMA64-b-PFHMAx diblock copolymers (these copolymers are denoted as H64-Fx for brevity; x = 200, 250 and 300) synthesized via RAFT dispersion polymerization in methanol at 65 °C and 15% w/w solids.
The structure of the resulting block copolymer was confirmed by 1H NMR
spectroscopy. Fig. 3B shows the 1H NMR spectrum of a representative sample PHPMA64-b-PFHMA250. Apart from the signals of PHPMA segments as denoted in Fig. 3A (note: HPMA actually comprises ~75 % 2-hydroxypropyl methacrylate with its minor isomer being 2-hydroxyisopropyl methacrylate), the characteristic signals of aromatic proton (k1, k2 and k3), aldehyde proton (i) and phenolic hydroxyl proton (j) for the FHMA block were also distinctly observed. The integration ratio of the aldehyde, phenolic hydroxyl and aromatic protons in the polymer was 1:1:3, indicating that the salicylaldehyde functionality remained intact during the RAFT dispersion polymerization.

The various colloidal dispersions obtained from the PHPMA64 macro-CTA
mediated dispersion polymerization of FHMA in methanol were analyzed by SEM to evaluate their nanoparticle morphologies (Fig. 4). Since the conversion of FHMA was > 99% in each case, the DPs of PFHMA block for PHPMA64-PFHMAx were regarded as equal to the targeted DP values. Well defined and uniform spheres with a mean diameter of ~ 80 nm were observed at a PFHMA DP of 200 (Fig. 4A). An increase of the PFHMA DP to 236 resulted in a mixed phase consisting of predominantly spherical nanoparticles of ~ 80 nm diameter and some short worm

species (Fig. 4B), whereas a mixed phase consisting of predominantly vesicle nanoparticles of 300-500 nm diameter and some longer worm species was observed when increasing the FHMA DP to 241(Fig. 4C). Further increasing the PFHMA DP to 250 led to the formation of a pure phase comprising polydisperse vesicles (Fig. 4D). SEM analyses indicated that pure worm phase could not be accessed from the PHPMA64 macro-CTA mediated dispersion polymerization of FHMA in methanol at 15 wt % solids. Concentration has proven to be significant for RAFT mediated PISA: higher concentrations significantly increase the probability of fusion events between the growing monomer-swollen particles, which are essential for the in situ evolution in nano-object morphology.23 In the present case, however, a pure worm phase was not accessible even for polymerizations conducted at a high solid content of 30 wt %, regardless of the targeted PFHMA block length. Presumably, the steric stabilization conferred by the relative long PHPMA64 stabilizer block was too high to allow efficient fusion of spheres into to worm morphology.56

Fig. 4 SEM images of nano-objects formed by PHPMA64-b-PFHMAx diblock copolymers prepared via RAFT dispersion polymerization in methanol at 65 oC and 15 % w/w solids for x = 200 (A) , 236 (B), 241 (C) and 250 (D).
Thus, in order to obtain a full range of pure copolymer morphologies (i.e.,
spheres, worms, and vesicles) another PHPMA macro-CTA with a shorter DP of 52 (PHPMA52 macro-CTA) was prepared and then evaluated for dispersion polymerization of FHMA. Like the case for PHPMA64 macro-CTA, a series of well-defined PHPMA52-PFHMAx block copolymers (with targeted x values of 60, 77, 84, 91, 98 and 150) could be obtained using PHPMA52 macro-CTA in methanol at 15 wt % solids, as evidenced by their narrow and unimodal GPC traces (Fig. 5). In all instances, near quantitative conversions (>99 %) of FHMA was attained after 24 h polymerizations as judged by 1H NMR analysis.

Fig. 5 GPC traces obtained for PHPMA52 macro-CTA and a series of PHPMA52-b-PFHMAx diblock copolymers (these copolymers are denoted as H52-Fx for brevity; x = 60, 91 and 150) synthesized via RAFT dispersion polymerization in methanol at 65 °C and 15% w/w solids.
The morphologies generated via in situ self-assembly of PHPMA52-PFHMAx block copolymers were investigated by SEM, and representative SEM images of the nanoparticles are shown in Fig. 6. Increasing the targeted DP of core forming PFHMA block from 60 to 150 led to a gradual evolution in morphology from spheres (Fig. 6A) to worms (Fig. 6C, D) to vesicles (Fig. 6F), with mixed phases between each of the these pure phases (Fig. 6B, E). In contrast to longer PHPMA64 macro-CTA used above, shorter PHPMA52 macro-CTA allowed not only spheres and vesicles but also worms.

Fig. 6. SEM images of nano-objects formed by PHPMA52-b-PFHMAx diblock copolymers prepared via RAFT dispersion polymerization in methanol at 65 oC and 15 % w/w solids for x = 60 (A), 77 (B), 84 (C), 91 (D), 95 (E) and 150 (F).
Formation of cross-linked fluorescent nano-objects with various morphologies An important feature of the as-prepared nanoparticles is the existence of salicylaldehyde functional groups in core-forming PFHMA blocks. Salicylaldehydes can react rapidly with hydrazine under mild conditions to form salicylaldazine with aggregation-induced emission (AIE) characteristics.47 In principle, one molecule hydrazine can react with two salicylaldehyde groups. Therefore, reaction of the as-prepared nanoparticles with hydrazine may enable their inherent nanostructures to be stabilized via covalent cross-linking within the core and simultaneously confer luminescent features on the resulting stabilized nanoparticles (Scheme 1).
Thus the polymerization dispersions (15 wt % solids) with pure copolymer
morphologies of sphere, worm and vesicle, formed by the above RAFT dispersion PISA of PHPMA52-PFHMA60, PHPMA52-PFHMA84 and PHPMA52-PFHMA150,

respectively, were diluted 5-fold with methanol. Then hydrazine hydrate was added to these diluted dispersions under stirring at room temperature. UV-vis spectrometry was used to follow the reaction between the salicylaldehyde-containing nano-objects and hydrazine hydrate. Fig. 7A shows representative UV-vis absorption spectra of PHPMA52-PFHMA60 nanoparticles in methanol upon gradual addition of hydrazine hydrate (0 - 0.6 equiv. to salicylaldehyde moieties). After addition of hydrazine hydrate, the absorption intensity at 228 nm and 264 nm due to π-π* and n-π* transition of C=O for PFHMA blocks decreased gradually, while two absorptions at 305 nm and 374 nm due to π-π* and n-π* transition of C=N for azines appeared and their intensity increased with the amount of added hydrazine hydrate,58 indicating the occurrence of salicylaldehyde–hydrazine condensing reaction. The UV-vis spectrum analysis also indicated that this salicylaldehyde–hydrazine reaction reached a saturation point at salicylaldehyde/hydrazine molar ratio of 0.5, as expected from the reaction stoichiometry. The salicylaldehyde–hydrazine reaction was also confirmed by FT-IR spectroscopy. Fig. 7 B shows typical FT-IR spectra of the PHPMA52-PFHMA60 spheres before (a) and after cross-linking (b). After cross-linking with hydrazine hydrate, the absorption band of aldehyde carbonyl group at ν = 1658 cm-1 decreased and the absorption band corresponding to imine group appeared at 1632 cm-1, demonstrating that the salicylaldehyde-hydrazine reaction did take place. It should be noted that the RAFT end-groups might be destroyed during cross-linking due to the hydrazidolysis of the trithiocarbonate groups.57

Fig. 7 UV-vis spectra (A) of PHPMA52-PFHMA60 copolymer nano-objects in methanol (3 % w/w total solids) upon gradual addition of hydrazine hydrate (0 – 0.6 equiv. to salicylaldehyde moieties) and FT-IR spectra (B) of the PHPMA20-PFHMA60 copolymer nano-objects before (a) and after cross-linking (b).
Solid nano-objects, obtained easily via precipitation into diethyl ether, could be
re-dispersed well in organic solvents such as methanol and THF. Although PHPMA stabilizer block is hydrophobic and therefore water-insoluble, the nano-objects could

also be re-dispersed in water at a low concentration (≤ 0.5 % w/w) to form colloidal dispersions, and their apparent sizes measured by DLS were almost the same as these for the re-dispersions in methanol. Presumably, the carboxylic acid end-groups conferred by the RAFT agent on the shell of the nano-object ensure the colloidal stability via charge stabilization. To test this hypothesis, the solution pH values were reduced from their initial 7.1 to 4.0 with dilute hydrochloric acid. At pH of 7.1, above the pKa of carboxylic acid group (pKa~ 4.8), the ionized carboxylic acid groups conferred charge stabilization on the nano-objects in water. At pH of 4.1, below the pKa of carboxylic acid group, flocculation did occur as ionization degree of the carboxylic acid groups decreased under acidic condition.
THF is a good solvent for linear PHPMA-PFHMA block copolymers, therefore
PHPMA-PFHMA nano-objects should disrupt into unimers in THF if they are not stabilized by covalent cross-linking. To verify whether PHPMA-PFHMA nano-objects had been stabilized after hydrazine cross-linking, these hydrazine-treated nano-objects were re-dispersed in THF and then analyzed by TEM (Fig. 8). By comparing their TEM images (Fig. 8B, D and F) with these observed before cross-linking (Fig. 8A, C and E, dispersed in methanol), it can be seen clearly that even after re-dispersing these hydrazine-treated nano-objects in THF their precise morphologies (spheres, worms or vesicles) remained intact, suggesting that PHPMA-PFHMA nano-objects are indeed stabilized via covalent cross-linking with hydrazine. Stability of the nano-assemblies structures is of great importance for their enhanced resistance to environment fluctuations or for their further modifications.

In addition to TEM studies, their apparent hydrodynamic diameters were
measured by DLS. The DLS sizes for the worms are not real sizes but represent only a mean for comparison. DLS results of the three nano-objects in methanol before and after cross-linking are shown in Fig. 9. A slight decrease in size can be observed after the cross-linking. The core cross-linking of the nano-objects results in a compact core, leading to a reduction in size, but the possible swelling of the cross-linked core containing polar salicylaldazine moieties in methanol causes the size to increase. In the present case, the former effect may exceed the latter, resulting in a slight size reduction after the cross-linking.
Fig. 9 Intensity-average diameter distributions of PHPMA52-PFHMA60 spheres (A), PHPMA52-PFHMA84 worms (B) and PHPMA52-PFHMA150 vesicles (C) in methanol before and after cross-linking.
Concomitantly, as shown in Fig. 10, after cross-linking with hydrazine the
resulting stabilized PHPMA-PFHMA nano-objects displayed strong orange fluorescence emission in both water and organic solvent THF (see inset pictures for represent examples of sphere nanoparticles) with maximum emission around 570

nm, while no fluorescence emission was observed in either water or THF before cross-linking. Cross-linking with hydrazine can bring about simultaneous formation of AIE fluorophores (i.e., salicylaldazine moieties) in the congested cores of spheres, worms or vesicles, thereby resulting in their strong fluorescence emission in both water and THF. The absolute fluorescence quantum yields of these nano-objects were determined to be 11.3 % (sphere), 11.0 % (worm) and 10.6% (vesicle) in water; 10.7 % (sphere), 11.2 % (worm) and 11.0 % (vesicle) in THF, thus it can be seen that the particle morphology or dispersion medium had a very small influence on the fluorescence emission since the AIE fluorophores were in a similar aggregation state in all cases. Unlike most organic fluorescent dyes whose fluorescence is quenched in solid states, these stabilized nano-objects also displayed orange fluorescence in solid states (Inset picture in Fig. 8F).

Fig. 10 Fluorescence spectra (λ ex = 390 nm) of the cross-linked copolymer nanoparticles dispersions in water (A) and THF (B) (0.1 wt %). Insets: Photographs of the cross-linked sphere nanoparticle dispersion in water (A) and THF (B).
All results indicated the successful preparation of cross-linked nano-objects of
various morphologies that show strong fluorescence emission in water, organic solvents, or solid states.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text:
RAFT dispersion polymerization of a newly designed slicylaldehyde-containing core-forming monomer FHMA was conducted at 15 % w/w solids in methanol at 65 oC using PHPMA macro-CTA as the stabilizer. As the PFHMA block grew, it becomes insoluble in the reaction medium, which drove the in situ formation of PHPMA-b-PHPMA diblock copolymer nano-objects via polymerization induced

self-assembly. By adjusting the chain length of core-forming block PFHMA, a wide range of morphologies such as sphere, worm and vesicle can be accessed. The salicylaldehyde groups of core-forming block PFHMA were subsequently reacted with hydrazine, endowing the PISA nano-objects with not only luminescent features but also cross-linking structure in consequence of the formation of salicylaldazine moieties within the nano-object cores. These resulting stabilized nano-objects could retain their morphology integrity in THF (good solvent for both blocks) and displayed strong orange fluorescence in water, organic solutions or solid states.

For Table of Contents Entry use only
Salicylaldehyde-functional nano-objects are prepared via RAFT-mediated
polymerization-induced self-assembly. Their simultaneous stabilization and
fluorescence modification can be achieved by one-step reaction.

metadata.abstractText: Salicylaldehyde-functional diblock copolymer nano-objects were synthesized by polymerization induced self-assembly (PISA) via RAFT dispersion polymerization of a newly designed core-forming monomer, 3-formyl-4-hydroxybenzyl methacrylate (FHMA), using poly(2-hydroxypropyl methacrylate) (PHPMA) macromolecular chain transfer agent as a steric stabilizer in methanol at 65 C. A range of PHPMA-b-PFHMA block copolymer morphologies including sphere, worm and vesicle could be accessed by adjusting the degree of polymerization of core forming block PFHMA. Since the salicylaldehyde groups of core-forming PFHMA blocks Page 1 of 32 Polymer Chemistry P ol ym er C he m is tr y A cc ep te d M an us cr ip t Pu bl is he d on 2 4 Ju ne 2 01 6. D ow nl oa de d by U ni ve rs ity o f Su ss ex o n 29 /0 6/ 20 16 0 8: 09 :2 0. View Article Online DOI: 10.1039/C6PY00794E
